we actually go through three stages of learning no matter what we're trying to do and these stages are cognitive which
is when we are just getting our head around a new skill associative which is when we need slightly less brain power
to do it just slightly less concentration and then autonomous this is when we can do things without having
to apply a lot of brainpower it's it's almost automatic execution for example

remembering the difference between accelerator and brake and exactly how to turn the steering wheel a teenage driver
who's been driving on their own for a few months is well into the associative stage of driving they can now listen to
the radio maybe carry on a conversation at the same time now we experienced
adults are all in the autonomous stage of driving and we can navigate the car to exactly where it needs to be whilst

neighbors and this is a pretty fear-inducing audience and in fact Steve Jobs was famous for creating fear
inducing and anxiety inducing performances so that he could practice his own presentations so just do
performances and presentations in front of people who you love and who love you even if they've got no idea what you are
talking about it still gets your adrenaline pumping and it's great practice I also ask my students to
record themselves and send me the first take and that creates adrenaline and
they they often don't want to send me the first take but too bad you've got to do it that's what it would be like in a
performance I get them to perform in nursing homes in concert halls obviously
not Carnegie Hall but I try to arrange as many performance opportunities for them as I can and this gets them used to
performing and if andrew and i did this particular presentation a few times at user groups
before we came to Norway I also get my students to keep playing while I'm
deliberately trying to distract them which they absolutely love but this is all part of the show must go on you have
to learn how to keep going in the face of adversity and finally I get them to do dress rehearsals I say what outfit
are you gonna wear on the day put that on try to simulate the performance situation as much as
possible so that's all about practicing performing now let's get to the actual
performance and this is where the seven deadly performance scenes come into it because even the very best preparation
can be totally derailed by committing any of these sins the first one is drawing attention to
mistakes which is what I was doing when I played the Mozart before now it's fine to make a mistake it's just not fine to
say oops or sorry or to repeatedly start again the audience does not care if a
performer makes a mistake we just need to ignore it and keep going correcting mistakes is another thing
particularly for musicians you know I say to my students if you play a wrong note just just ignore it if you try to
fix the wrong note the audience doesn't sit there going AHA that was the pitch I was waiting for
all they notice is a total disruption in the flow the rhythm has been lost so we
don't correct mistakes we just ignore them deadly performance scene number three is starting to fast and that is
definitely what I did when I played the mozart before and then i had to slow down in order to cope with the faster
section and the reason that we start too fast or the reason we talk too fast is because of adrenaline and performing
gives us adrenalin it's really handy if we're trying to outrun a wild beast in
the jungle but it's not great when we're trying to speak clearly in front of people or play Mozart so the more we
practice performing the more we can manage the power of adrenalin performance in number four is altering
the conditions now that's what I did when I decided at the last minute to have my hair down instead of up and then my hair got in my
face I've got a picture of heels here because one time I did select a lovely
pair of heels for a performance and I ended up with a cramp in my calf while I was playing because I hadn't practiced like that and if you alter the
conditions at the last minute you put yourself up to any number of things that can go wrong and pleats have a fantastic
saying for this they say nothing new on race day and as performers and presenters we can take a lot away from
that performance in number five showing a dissatisfaction so I tell my students
they have to have a poker face doesn't matter how badly you think the performance is going you don't slump or
Tut or frown because that just broadcasts to everybody that it's going wrong and usually an audience won't
notice it's very important to appear gracious and that includes after the
performance if somebody comes up to you and says oh my goodness I loved your playing you have to smile say thank you
even if you didn't like it don't apologize or say sorry or it was awful performance in number six breaking
the spell so when a performer or a presenter looks somewhere unexpectedly
it distracts the audience so that's what I did during the mozart when andrew
started coughing i looked over at him and that distracted you and if i hadn't have done that maybe his coughing fit
would have gone unnoticed well okay that was a pretty spectacular coughing fit but as long as the performer keeps going
it's really important not to interrupt what is essentially a listening reverie from the audience and finally
performance in number seven ignoring the audience which is what I did I walked
straight to the keyboard and I walked straight off and I didn't bow and that's actually very rude of a performer to do
and I I tell my students that they must bow if the audience is clapping then you
must bow because bowing is the way of saying thank you for clapping for me so
if the audience is clapping and you're not bowing it's rude it's like not saying to thank you for something
there's actually being researched to show that the way you present yourself on stage makes a huge difference to how
the audience will enjoy your performance people were asked to rate performances on mute they didn't get to listen to any
music they could only watch the gestures of the performer and those who had a confident stage entry with a smile and a
nod and a bow those performances rated higher even though they couldn't hear what was being played so loving the
audience is so important okay so we've done practice we've done practice performing and we've covered performing
